results.content:
The course is presented with decent visual and audio quality. It covers some of the fundamentals of javascript and how it can interact with HTML elements in web pages. It is as he indicates in his course wrap up, a very quick "get your hands dirty" type course.

This course won't have you up and coding beautiful websites in an hour. It also won't make it through all of the fundamentals such as FOR loops, but it will provide you a quick and easy to understand intro to javascript in relation to webpages.

If it does whet your appetite for coding or javascript in particular, check out some of the more lengthy courses here on udemy. John has quite a few 1-hour intro style courses; those that I've used are all of good quality production and give you a good idea of what the language/software feels like. 

Cost is my only concern and I have the same issue with most of Udemy's content, really. I found another source for learning javascript that I think is phenomenal but it is a subscription based model. If you need a more in depth javascript course that won't expire, check out some of the other courses here at Udemy.

results.content:
Lecture Two is called "Introduction."  Funny, Lecture One was already an introduction.  Don't these Udemy folks have any editors?

Listening on more, I'm just annoyed by all the gabble gabble gabble and the Um, uh, the reason is is...

If you're putting a course out in front of a public -- and even sometimes taking money from people -- you have an obligation not to waste their time.  This means that at minimum you script yourself, listen to what you've recorded, erase and re-record where there are stupid errors, and just generally apply a little discipline.

This kid is wasting our time -- but Udemy is wasting this kid's time by not giving him the guidance and control he needs.
-dlj.

results.content: I took this course because it was offered for free.  Had I paid the full price for it, I would have been very disappointed.  There are 18 "lectures" but 3 of them are less than 2 minutes long; hardly enough time to be considered a "lecture."  The instructor should take some time to collect his thoughts before he hits the record button... I get the impression that he has a rough idea what he wants to talk about but then just wings it and each lesson ends up being scattered and very fast.  Some lessons seem like they are actually afterthoughts to the previous lessons... things that should have been mentioned but forgotten.  But by far, my biggest complaint is that I don't think he does a good job picking a target audience.  He says it's for the absolute beginner, but he'll throw around terms like "functions", pseudo-code", and "objects" which may be foreign terms to a beginner.  He makes assumptions that a user understands HTML, but then introduces things like comments.  For a free overview, it gives you an idea what JS can do, but it doesn't really teach you basic fundamentals.  But for $30, it's really a waste of money given the amount of resources that are available online.   I'll give points for the audio and video quality, but I can't say that the course delivered on its promise to "learn" Javascript.  Sorry.

results.content:
Given that the duration of the course was only one hour, it is impressive how many concepts you learn throughout the experience.

The teaching was informative and taught me a few things about JavaScript.

The course would be better improved if it had a quick summary about other simple concepts in JavaScript such as: Prompt, document.write, concatenation, incrementing coolNumber(to make it do different things).

Would recommend this course to other beginners.
